metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: Housing Officias to Confer  Next Week on City"s Needs  JAN 30 1943  Edward D. Cement, executive  secretary for the Housing Authority  of the City of Charleston, will  leave Tuesday for Atanta to attend a meeting with Robert K.  Creighton, of the regional housing  office, Wednesday, to discuss Additional housing facilities needed to  care for 14,000 new war workers  expected to come here this year for  the Charleston navy yard.  Mayor Henry W. ockwood yesterday    received    a    letter    from United States Senator Burnet R.  Maybank saying that the Federal  housing authority already has made  a survey in Charleston to determine  these housing needs.  John D. Bandford, Jr., national  housing administrator, submitted a  statement showing that 10,141 living units to provide housing for war  workers are competed, under construction, under contract or in process of being awarded to contract.  following is a table showing the  housing situation here as revealed  in the survey.  family HOUSING:Tota   Competed Under Construction or Contract    Net Yet Under Contract  Publicy financed  5,857 2,047 3,810  privately financed 2,665 512 724 1,429 Sub-tota  8,522 2,559 4,534 1,429  HOUSING FOR COUPES:,  Publicy financed   750  ---  500   250  DORMITORIES:  Publicy financed    869 519  350   Tota   10,141   3,078  5,384  1,679   Status as of December 31, 1942.    Status as  of November 30,  1942.     To be provided by remodeing existing structures.
